And here are the flashcards:

Q: What is the problem with the traditional nomenclature for lung sounds?
A: It is imprecise.
Extra: The traditional way of naming lung sounds is not accurate enough, which led to the need for a new and more specific terminology.

Q: Who proposed a new terminology for lung sounds?
A: International Lung Sounds Association.
Extra: The International Lung Sounds Association proposed a new terminology for lung sounds to provide a more accurate and specific way of classifying these sounds.

Q: What is the replacement for the term "rale" in the new terminology?
A: "Crackle"
Extra: The term "rale" was replaced with "crackle" in the new terminology proposed by the International Lung Sounds Association. "Crackle" can be defined acoustically and does not suggest any specific means or site of generation.

Q: Where can the clinical characteristics of normal and adventitious sounds be found?
A: Table 1.
Extra: The clinical characteristics of normal and adventitious sounds can be found in Table 1 in this article.

Q: Where can the lung sounds be heard?
A: Interactive graphic available at NEJM.org.
Extra: The lung sounds can be heard in an interactive graphic that is available with the full text of this article at NEJM.org.
